title: Ticket #353: Fix streaming of input, output, etc. on Windows
description:
On Windows, when streaming input, output, etc. are requested in the submit file, the starter would crash upon launching the job's executable.

It turns out that we were closing fds that did not exist, when we should have been using the fd value as an index into the list of windows pipe handles.
remarks:
2009-Mar-27 13:06:36 by tannenba:
Is [14292] safe on Unix, or should there be an #ifndef WIN32 in condor_close()? On Unix, what does daemonCore->Close_Pipe() do differently than just a close?

2009-Mar-27 13:49:23 by burnett:
It appears that streaming I/O does not function on Windows. An account from NMI puts the first occurrence of the service not functioning at version 6.7.18, but it may have not worked for much longer than this, as the comment that mentioned it was only put in place after the first time NMI started testing streaming I/O on Windows.

2009-Mar-27 14:04:16 by burnett:
I'm not sure if an #ifdef will make inherently "safer", but it seems, to me, that the logic for creating fds should all go through DaemonCore, so that we don't run into these cases where it is clear that close() is not system agnostic.

2009-Mar-28 08:48:44 by gthain:
This commit caused all kinds of test breakage, so I reverted it on the trunk.

2009-Mar-30 14:08:05 by tannenba:
Ben, any theories about all the breakage, and/or thoughts about what to do now? (obviously this ticket is not resolved, so re-opening it)

2009-Mar-30 16:09:56 by burnett:
That is really strange; I'll take a closer look at it in the morning. It appeared that daemonCore->*_Pipe() family were doing the correct thing, from the looks of the #ifdef 'ery; perhaps, however, it doesn't work at all, or there are some special cases that it does not account for.
